message: Nope, this is *very* standard. Django + PostgreSQL for the most part.
Not AFAIK
Are you using Django's templating at all or is most of this JS templates?
@bryan Actually almost all is Django templating.  We haven't done any JS templating yet, but there's a few spots where we have minimal inline html in our javascript (sucks, I know, but it's minimal)
Sorry, was introducing my wife to Convore. Really, Django and Postgres? Awesome
And we use some Celery to do some lightweight offline tasks.
but rails is for ajax!
Ooo. I see some LocalStorage goings on.
Are you guys using Riak to back all of this?
redis too right?
Yep, just super standard stuff.  We figure we need flexibility and the ability to change stuff easily if it doesn't work, and once we hit the right featureset, then we can focus on scalability.
what? no node.js? no sproutcore? How will this ever be new hotness?
Redis is used as a queue and for the live endpoint.
The live endpoint is a pure-wsgi app powered by Eventlet
@ericflo excellent. though I would've thought a little node.js would've been sprinkled. (JOKING!) lol
@asenchi Actually we thought about that, for socket.io, but the way all the node.js Redis clients all work didn't work the way we needed it to.
@justinlilly that's twice tonight we've had nearly the same thought. /scared
@ericflow what are you using JS library wise?
guess you'll have to settle for being merely "stable and popular"
@mintchaos https://convore.com/media/js/
It's jQuery, a few plugins, and then our custom javascript
The bulk of it is in convore.stream.js
@bryan Yeah, actually, we only really needed a cookie, but for whatever reason the cookie wasn't working
It's just to handle a race condition where a message comes in after the page has loaded but before the javascript has executed and started listening for live events
@ericflo no cassandra?
@neil hah, nope
@ericflo gunicorn or flup?
https://convore.com/admin/
nooooo
what all 3rd party apps are you guys using?
South, gravatar, pagination, compressor, djcelery, haystack
oh, and cuddlybuddly.storage.s3
@neil http://dpaste.de/SibS/
@neil At one point we were using Eventlet coroutines to do messaging, now it's redis but at one point it wasn't.  Also for background tasks we used to just spawn a coroutine too
@neil eventlet.wsgi
@ericflo looks pretty simple.  any reason you're using straight eventlet over gunicorn with eventlet workers?
I am @ericflo's sheep. I swear that every time he mentions a technology I haven't taken a look at, I can expect to drain 5 hours researching it. EC2 had to have been the latest shot.
With that said, I'm looking at eventlet now. >_>;
@ericflo Yeah, I noticed the footer. I gave up anyway, and the prices just seemed too steep for my lowly and underfunded ventures. :P
I'm considering switching to ec2 micro instances if/when they support BSD
Haha, sorry @bryan!
BTW @bryan I should mention we didn't end up moving to EC2, for some non-technical reasons.
9.10 specifically
also want to start using postgres exclusively, but mahalo will keep me in mysql land for a time to come.
i have to keep a php cluster up for a vbulletin install i run
I didn't even bother. I wanted the simplest thing evar.
@justinlilly i think you mentioned earlier, but where are you now?
@justinlilly d'oh. was referring to where you were moving from onto ec2 when they get bsd support =)
Ubuntu.
i'm using linode for a couple of UbunAMphp stacks, but want to move some of my other stuff of of slice
relevant software on mine..  ubuntu, nginx, gunicorn, mysql, php (via fast_cgi), postgres, django, flask, er.. oh, and a git server
sounds similar to my slice+linodes, though i use uWSGI instead of gunicorn
@jacob I'm in NYC at the moment, but moving to Seattle in ~2.5 weeks.
@jacob Rackspace Cloud. See the VPS thread on FreeBSD for my reasoning.
what os are you using on RSC?
